reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s setup of evaluating “mostly-great futures” under a baseline distribution with “no serious coordinated de dicto optimization,” arguing that once such stakes are articulated, incentives push actors to politicize and Goodhart proxies, collapsing the baseline assumption and producing authoritarian/metric-gamed steering. This is moderately central: if the baseline distribution is ill-posed or unstable under reflection/publication, that weakens the practical applicability of the essay’s ‘target size’ claims, but it does not directly refute the core normative/philosophical thesis that value is fragile or that many moral views are fussy. Strength is limited because the essay already distinguishes ‘target size’ from navigation/steering forces and explicitly brackets optimization pressure; the critique mostly says the bracket is unrealistic, without showing that the conceptual comparison (easy vs no-easy eutopia) can’t be made or that the conclusion is false under the intended conditional. It also relies on contestable game-theoretic predictions (inevitable defection/authoritarian equilibrium, no incentive-compatible separation), which are plausible but not demonstrated. Correctness is moderate: Goodhart/metric gaming and politicization risks are real, but the ‘immediate’ and ‘no stable way’ claims are overstated. Clarity is fairly good: a coherent failure mechanism is described, though key terms (proxy, incentive-compatible, equilibrium) aren’t operationalized. Dead weight is low: most sentences contribute to the single main line. It largely focuses on one issue (incentives/Goodhart undermining the conditional framework), with only minor extra rhetorical framing.
title: Fussy eutopia framing invites strategic defection and authoritarian Goodharting
